titleStmt.title: WILL WOOD's Petition to the PEOPLE of
IRELAND, being an excellent new Song.

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: Supposed to be made and sung in the Streets of Dublin, by William Wood, Ironmonger, and Halfpenny-monger, 1725.
MY dear Irish Fokes,Come leave off your Jokes,
And buy up my Halfpence so fine;So fair and so bright,They'll give you Delight;
Observe how they glister and shine.They'll sell to my GriefAs cheap as Neck-beef,
For Counters at Cards to your Wife:And every DayYour Children may play
Span-farthing or Toss on the Knife.
Come hither and try, I'll teach you to buy
A Pot of good Ale for a Farthing:Come; Three-pence a Score,I ask you no more,
And a Fig for the Drapier and 1The Drapier's Printer.Harding.
When Tradesmen have Gold, The Thief will be bold,
By Day and by Night for to rob him:My Copper is such,No Robber will touch,
And, so you may daintily bob him.
The little Black-guard Who gets very hard
His Halfpence for cleaning your Shoes:When his Pockets are cramm'dWith mine, and be d────'d,
He may swear he has nothing to lose.
Here's Halfpence in Plenty, For one you'll have twenty,
Tho' Thousands are not worth a Pudden:Your Neighbours will think,When your Pocket cries Chink,
You are grown plaguy rich on a sudden.
You will be my Thankers, I'll make you my Bankers,
As good as 1Two famous Bankers.Ben Burton or Fade:For nothing shall pass,But my pretty Brass,
And then you'll be all of a Trade.
I'm a Son of a Whore, If I have a Word more
To say in this wretched Condition:If my Coin will not pass,I must die like an Ass,
And so I conclude my Petition.H5210802
